g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Technological innovation may bring significant synergy in pursuing sustainable development goals, but
it may also create challenges to the economy, human well
2019; Schillo and Robinson 2017; Walsh et al. 2020)
. The degree of potential synergies and trade
among SDG differs from country to country and over time (see section 16.6.1.1). These potentials will
depend upon available resources, geographical conditions, development stage and policy measures.

production and consumption patterns, as well as in value chains and in the wider economy, requires
clarification. Technology ownership and control together with its
productivity needs to be revised if a meaningful contribution to the implementation of the SDGs in a
transformative way is to be achieved

emphasises the need for capacity development along with international collaboration projects

Other actions with the potential to maximize synergies are those related to community or â€œgrassrootâ€
technological innovation. The importance of the link between technological innovation and community
tion and its contribution to sustainable development is usually underestimated, and requires further
research and, most importantly, its inclusion in the political agenda on sustainable development
. On the other hand, when technological inno
vation occurs far from where is
implemented and participation in the production, and hence training activities of local actors is minimal,
benefits and synergies among SDGs are limited and usually far below expectations
